title: Not another house-cleaning ... Lame-duck status might put jolt into Blue Bombers
text:
The bandwagon has cleared right out, leaving only the loyalists. And they, too, are grumbling.
Some are even cursing the fact they were fooled yet again into believing in Blue.
This season was going to be different for the Bombers.
The head coach and GM had a year under their belts, enough time to leave their stamps on the roster, game plans and coaching staff.
In a league where a second-year expansion team has won eight of 13 games, Mike O’Shea and Kyle Walters have had time to restore some of the shine on this yellowing and pitted franchise by building a playoff team, one that could make some noise heading into a home Grey Cup.
Yet at 4-10 and sinking like a stone, it’s been more of the same, the Bombers assured only of finishing with a losing record for the seventh time in the last eight years.
So what to do?
The easy response would be to make like Molly Maid and clean house. Again.
Toss one or both out the door and start all over.
Geez, how many times have we gone through that?
Since 1991, the year after they won their last championship, the Bombers have had seven different head coaches and four different GM’s (Mike Kelly didn’t hold that title, but he was in charge of all things football).
They say a GM should get to hire at least two coaches before his own head is on the block.
But Walters hasn’t earned that luxury by building a winner elsewhere. It looks more and more like he just hasn’t supplied the horses for his head coach.
Which brings us to O’Shea.
What’s that they say — if you don’t learn from history, you’re doomed to repeat it?
Some recent history, then, for the Bombers to learn from.
It was after the 2000 season, and then-head coach Dave Ritchie’s seat was getting warm.
Ritchie, like O’Shea, had taken over a mess. The Bombers had gone 3-15 in 1998, the same feeble record they had in 2013, when O’Shea took over.
Ritchie went just 6-12 his first season, then 7-10-1 in Year 2, sneaking into a playoff spot. Not exactly fever-pitch progress.
Going into the third and final year of his contract, Gramps, as some in the front office called him, was under the gun: his deal called for a fourth year only if he managed a winning record through three.
Technically, Ritchie had to go 14-4 in 2001 to keep getting paid.
And that’s exactly what he did.
Then-CEO Lyle Bauer actually handed him an extension before that season was over, when the Bombers were well into a 12-game win streak. But you get the point.
Ritchie’s lame-duck status was well known going into that season. And his players, who loved him, came through for him.
Fast forward to the present.
O’Shea’s Bombers went 7-11 his first year. Year 2 they could still sneak into a playoff spot, whether they deserve it or not, with a losing record.
O’Shea’s players, still playing hard, seem to love him, too. And why wouldn’t they? He backs them even when they don’t deserve it.
So with one more year on his deal, the answer seems obvious.
Send him into 2016 with the heat on high.
Let’s see if that injects a little more urgency into everything he does, from roster decisions to who he hires and fires on his coaching staff.
And let’s see, just as importantly, how his players react.
Because last time I checked, winning was the only way to keep your job in professional sports.
So I wouldn’t worry about a lame duck.
It’s the dead duck we’ve seen all too often.
STILL FIGHT IN BOMBERS
The Winnipeg Blue Bombers will begin practice Tuesday for a must-win game in B.C., trying to regroup from their latest crushing loss.
“Definitely going to need some time to recover from this loss,” receiver Clarence Denmark said following Saturday’s 24-23 heartbreaker against Edmonton. “We’ve still got to fight. We’ve got to still be pros.”
Denmark at least returns to work knowing he had his best game since mid-July, hauling in three passes for 95 yards.
Kicker Lirim Hajrullahu has to pick himself up after missing four field goals and his sixth convert of the year.
“He’s going to be all right. I believe in Lirim,” kick returner Troy Stoudermire said.
Stoudermire was one of the players who tried to pick up their kicker before he attempted, and made, his last field goal with just over a minute to go.
“I know you’re not really supposed to talk to him. But he was down,” Stoudermire said.
Edmonton kicker Sean White nailed a 53-yarder on the last play for the win.
The Bombers could audition import kicker Sergio Castillo this week in practice.
HOG’S HEAD UP
Centre Dominic Picard insists he’s not tired of saying his team, now 4-10, is close.
“We’re looking around us and we believe,” Picard said. “We’re still in in it, that’s the crazy thing.”
Picard liked the play of the hogs, as the Bombers held Edmonton without a sack.
“Up front we picked up their blitzes. We handled their front pretty well,” he said. “We were physical. And we put a toll on these guys ... we’ve got to find a way to close the deal.”
PAUL FRIESEN
